0.60.text:
Hey, it’s Marie Forleo and you are watching
MarieTV, the place to be to create a business

12.21.text:
And today is a very special day because I
get to introduce you to someone who’s been

16.63.text: a teacher and a mentor in my life.

19.46.text:
Colleen Saidman Yee is an internationally
respected yoga teacher who has been teaching

25.65.text:
Before that she was a top fashion model with
Elite and Ford and also lived in Calcutta

31.67.text:
She’s the founder of Yoga Shanti in Sag
Harbor and, along with her husband Rodney

36.51.text:
Yee, other studios in West Hampton and New
York City.

40.39.text:
Colleen has been featured in Vanity Fair,
Yoga Journal, New York Magazine, Oprah, Marie

47.84.text:
In her new book, Yoga for Life, we learn about
how she went from a rebellious young woman

52.66.text:
with a heroin habit to a globe-trotting fashion
model to, as the New York Times calls her,

60.20.text: Colleen, thank you so much for being here.

66.06.text:
So if you guys don't know, Colleen has been
my yoga teacher for almost 10 years now.

73.22.text:
Started taking class with you back in 2006
and, I have to tell you, before I started

78.79.text:
practicing with you and then with you and
Rodney, I liked yoga but it wasn’t anything

84.21.text:
that I felt so drawn to, and you have been
such a great teacher in my life.

89.72.text:
Like, every summer when I come out to practice
with you it’s like you help bring me back

94.46.text: to myself, and thank you for that.

97.59.text: And I wanted to congratulate you.

100.93.text: I read this book cover to cover.

107.22.text:
And something struck me that you said right
in the beginning.

110.87.text:
You start off the book saying, “Know you’re
enough.”

115.17.text:
And you write, “I watch women holding it
together afraid that if they slow down everything

121.64.text:
I watch women being ashamed that they’re
aging and feeling unworthy of love.

126.47.text:
Women in my classes coping with addiction
and body and relationship issues, mother issues,

131.43.text:
competitive issues, and an inability to tell
the truth.”

135.97.text:
I read that and my heart simultaneously broke,
because I saw myself in it, and it opened

142.22.text: up because it was such a sense of relief.

146.03.text:
When I read the book I got the sense that
you too are on this journey.

150.78.text:
How have you experienced this idea of you’re
enough?

157.91.text: How does that make sense in your life now?

161.58.text:
The first time I heard that phrase was actually
a month into writing the book and I’m like,

168.45.text: “Who am I to write a book?

170.50.text:
I didn't even graduate college, for heaven’s
sakes.”

174.38.text:
And my agent was like, “Just every day sit
down and write for an hour, just any story

182.59.text:
We were in Paris, London, Morocco, teaching
around the globe.

187.48.text:
So I was doing that and I was hitting a wall
and music is my inspiration, always has been,

195.78.text:
So I started listening to this Jason Isbell
song and the lyric was, “Cover me up and

207.38.text: I’ve been running for my whole life.”

211.15.text:
You know, covering up or running or trying
to show the world something that I wasn’t

216.27.text: for fear that I wasn’t enough.

219.74.text:
And it just, like you said, it broke something
open in me and I thought, “You know what?

231.74.text:
Mine in some ways may be more dramatic or
in some cases less dramatic, but to have people

238.30.text:
know, A, they’re not alone and, B, they
are enough.

242.34.text:
And if we could break the armor at the very
first line of my book it says that if one

248.52.text:
woman would stand up and tell her story, the
whole universe would break open.

259.32.text:
Tear the armor, show the world who you are,
and give other women confidence to do the

265.44.text:
Funny, I was scouring the internet one night
when I was having a hard time sleeping and

272.14.text:
watching YouTube videos and there’s this
video of Fiona Apple, and I was mesmerized.

280.74.text:
She was dancing and singing and it was really
jerky.

285.25.text:
Like, it wasn’t beautiful, it wasn’t graceful,
but something in her touched me so deeply.

291.73.text:
It was like this woman is wounded and she
is not afraid to show that.

297.00.text:
I felt like it was like this beautiful namaste,
right?

304.25.text:
My dance may have a limp, but the dance with
the limp is almost more beautiful than a dance

311.06.text:
There’s... that’s what I get, that’s
why I come back to your class and your work

315.24.text:
again and again, because I constantly feel
that okayness in my own self.

320.78.text:
Now, you’ve been teaching for almost 20
years now?

325.89.text:
When you were first getting your training
at  Jivamukti, you have a story in the book

330.77.text:
about the fact that you were so into this
training, yoga was such a huge breakthrough

335.15.text:
in your own life, all the other things that
you went through, and you walked in and you

339.37.text:
said, you know, “I just wanna do this for
my own personal development and my own practice.

345.87.text:
It was about two thirds of the way through
the training and I just had this realization

352.21.text: of, “Oh, I’m not gonna do this.

354.65.text:
I am not going to get up in front of people
and teach yoga.

361.73.text:
I’m not going to and I need to let Sharon
and David know that now.”

366.68.text:
Well, I walked into their office and it was...
it was literally almost like they expected

372.18.text:
They’re sitting there and I’m going through
my list of reasons why I just want to let

375.71.text:
you know now that I have no intention of being
a yoga teacher and these are the reasons.

381.71.text:
I’m shy, I am not the one to get up in front
of the classroom and speak my truth or chant,

394.24.text:
because I am also tone deaf, so that’s just
not gonna work here.

399.25.text:
And I also have epilepsy, and you never know
when a seizure is gonna come on.

403.26.text:
And can you imagine how mortified I would
be and traumatized the classroom would be?

410.56.text:
So I told them all and they listened and they
were very gracious and graceful.

414.27.text:
And so I left and about an hour later I get
a phone call.

422.69.text: Sharon Gannon, my... my teacher, my mentor.

426.64.text: And she said, “Hello Colleen, this is Sharon.”

431.43.text:
She said, “You’re teaching my 6:15 class
tonight.

435.49.text:
It’s already sold out and I’ll be taking
the class.”

445.89.text: And what did you feel in that moment?

458.25.text:
You know those moments when you actually can’t
see, hear, think, feel?

463.26.text:
So I... it was three and a half hours of prep
and I went home and I memorized every single

471.40.text:
I still remember the sequence to this day
that I taught.

475.97.text:
I think it’s the most nervous I have ever
been.

479.83.text:
But I got up there, I remember Sharon was
in the back right corner, I remember exactly

485.02.text: what she was wearing, it was just so surreal.

490.76.text:
So I taught the class and I walked outta there
high as a kite.

496.79.text:
It was just so... for some reason I don't
love the word empowering, but it’s the only

503.24.text:
word that comes to me right now is it was
just so...

505.94.text:
I was like, “If I can do this, there’s
a lot more possibilities in life that could

513.00.text:
I’d put myself in such a shell as a fashion
model for so many years and being exonerated

521.51.text:
for my external appearance that my internal
life had gotten pretty dilapidated.

529.15.text:
So to be able to stand up there in front of
75 people including one of the women that

533.74.text:
I respect most in the world and teach a class
and walk out and feel like I did a pretty

540.41.text:
good job for my first class, it was... and
I’ve had a lot of unnatural highs in my

546.40.text: life and this one was just... just amazing.

552.28.text:
So did you really believe when you walked
in that room that you would never teach?

557.69.text:
I knew I would never... it wasn’t even a
belief, it was solid.

563.89.text:
Isn’t that so incredible that another woman
standing up, seeing something in you beyond

570.65.text:
what you could see in yourself at that point
and then now I have the benefit and thousands

575.14.text:
and tens of thousands and millions of people
have the benefit of your teaching.

581.04.text: Yeah, she threw me off the cliff.

583.04.text:
And she knew she had to do it right away or
I was gonna turn and run.

586.44.text:
And that for me in my life too, so many times
if I’ve been thrown in the fire is when

590.65.text:
I discover my strength and it’s those people
that are willing to push me off the ledge

598.25.text:
One of the other questions that I had was
around your experience with Mother Teresa,

603.07.text:
and it so warmed my heart that you were writing
these letters to her since you were a little

608.07.text:
girl and then 17 years later a letter came
back.

612.71.text: Can you tell us about that?

616.37.text:
I read an article in Life magazine, do you
remember Life magazine?

622.05.text:
And it was pictures of Mother Teresa serving
the poorest of the poor.

627.41.text:
And I was, I’m guessing, 11 or 12 at the
time and I have 5 brothers and was feeling

638.20.text:
very overwhelmed and I was like, “Ok, this
is the answer.”

642.54.text:
Looking at her, looking at the peace and the
love, and I was deep into Catholicism as a

648.89.text:
And so I just wrote her letters and I told
her all of my problems and I said, “You

653.05.text:
might think I’m joking because I’m young,
but I really want to work with you.”

657.09.text:
At the time I thought I was going to be a
nun.

658.72.text:
I hadn’t had sex yet, so the nunnery was
still an option for me.

663.85.text:
And I didn't hear back, I didn't really expect
to hear back, and then I’d write a couple

668.66.text:
more times, 54 A Circular Drive Calcutta,
India.

673.72.text:
And then, yeah, 17 years later an envelope
came from a woman named Sister Priscilla and

680.36.text:
it said, “You are ready to serve the poorest
of the poor.”

686.85.text:
And it had just come at a time that I had
just broken up from a 16, 17 year relationship,

697.30.text:
And when you got there, that experience of
actually doing the work, what did that teach

706.19.text:
Concisely it taught me that the only way to
peace is through service.

711.99.text: And the nuns taught that day in and day out.

717.48.text:
Mother Teresa has this beautiful saying, apparently
it’s written in her chambers, and it says

723.97.text:
that the fruit of silence is prayer, the fruit
of prayer is faith, the fruit of faith is

731.60.text:
love, the fruit of love is service, and the
fruit of service is peace.

737.56.text: And it was just so beautiful.

741.57.text:
The whole time I was there I had two dresses
and I’d wash one out every night and then

747.24.text:
And, I mean, coming from the fashion world
where it was all about makeup and designer

751.55.text:
clothes and the best hair, I wasn’t ever
really as happy as I was in India.

757.78.text:
I’d shaved my head, I was wearing these
really quite ugly, I still have them, they’re

763.36.text:
hanging in my closet next to my other Herve
Leger and whatever else.

768.44.text:
But I just found out that I could be happy
without all of that extra stuff.

773.89.text:
I still love the extra stuff, don't get me
wrong, but there is a place deep inside that

779.62.text:
can be touched and it is peace and it comes
through service, and that was the main lesson...

788.49.text:
I mean, at one point when I was in India I
was working at this home called Prem Dom and

794.25.text: it’s mainly for the mentally unstable.

799.25.text:
And I was given the assignment to wash a man
that had elephantitis of the testicles, which

809.95.text:
And I’m watching the nuns and could tell
it was a test for me, and I realized that

818.57.text:
And whatever you want to call God, it became
a privilege and an honor and I felt peace.

831.49.text:
The next piece in the book that really got
me was about this idea of impermanence.

839.17.text:
And there’s something that you wrote that,
again, was another moment, I’m reading it,

842.89.text: and I felt myself wanting to cry.

844.85.text: “What’s the use of working so hard?

848.55.text:
My yoga studio won’t last, my students will
die, I’ll die.

852.49.text:
Why bother waking up every morning and teach
yoga?

855.61.text:
Why bother loving when our loved ones will
eventually be taken away from us?”

859.42.text:
And you shared that you come back to the Mother
Teresa quote, “What you spend years creating

864.51.text:
someone could destroy overnight and create
anyway.”

867.39.text: Yeah, but that’s the big yoga lesson, really.

872.23.text:
It’s everything that we put so much stock
in is transitory.

879.83.text:
And suffering comes from clinging on or pushing
away the stuff that’s just changing all

886.32.text:
So what’s the point of doing anything then,
if it’s all changing?

889.75.text: I mean, that’s like this big question.

892.81.text:
There’s sometimes if I’m pushing myself
so hard and I’ll, you know, crash in my

897.11.text: bed and go, “What am I doing this for?”

898.61.text:
And that’s why this passage moved me so
much.

901.84.text:
I think the answer to that is if you don't
then you freaking sleep through this beautiful

909.73.text:
All we have, like, all we have right now is
this amazing moment between the two of us.

913.87.text:
That’s what we have and that’s real and
that’s now.

916.53.text:
Whereas if we’re thinking about something
that could happen tomorrow or something or

921.92.text:
some remorse from something, we’re not awake,
we’re not present, and then we end up, as

927.39.text:
Mary Oliver said, “What are you gonna do
with this one precious life of yours?”

933.09.text:
And we do want to be awake for our life, we
want to be present.

936.85.text:
We don't want it to be a blur that we haven’t
felt, seen, lived, touched, breathed, just

941.93.text:
embraced and enveloped the moment whether
it’s a moment of intense grief or beauty

952.35.text: It’s just... it’s the real stuff.

954.15.text: It is the real stuff and it is important.

957.79.text:
Every time I start to feel myself going to
that clinging, thinking about Josh or my family

964.01.text:
or planning for the days that inevitably you
know will come, and I come back to this work

969.78.text:
or come back on my mat on a class with you
and it feels like I get in touch with that

973.74.text: peace, and that’s just so important.

975.46.text:
There’s a Mark Twain quote that comes back
to me.

983.92.text:
I’m here to say I’m working on it, I’ve
got the Catholic guilt thing going on and

991.62.text:
But there’s this Mark Twain quote and he
says, “I am a very old man and I look back

997.35.text: at my life and I’ve had so many difficulties.

1005.38.text:
It’s like we spend so much, we waste so
much energy and we’re tired enough.

1012.38.text: We don't need to waste energy there.

1014.14.text:
So the last thing I wanna go over with you,
I think one of my favorite parts of being

1019.03.text:
on the mat and being in the class with you
is always at the end you bring us home and

1024.60.text:
it’s the talk at the end and I feel like
I walk out and the poses were great and the

1028.73.text:
asanas were great and the breathing was great,
but there’s something that you always touch

1031.47.text:
in me and I feel like it’s in this book
and it’s the Buddhist meditation about fear.

1036.21.text: Would you read that for us?

1043.41.text: Notice where you feel hard and sit with that.

1049.21.text:
In the middle of that hardness you’ll find
anger.

1058.12.text:
Go to the center of the anger and you’ll
probably come to sadness.

1067.34.text: Stay with the sadness until it turns to vulnerability.

1073.36.text: Keep sitting with what comes up.

1077.12.text: The deeper you dig, the more tender you become.

1081.87.text:
Raw fear can open into the wide expanse of
genuineness, compassion, gratitude, and acceptance

1095.14.text:
A tender heart appears naturally when you
are able to stay present.

1101.59.text:
From your heart you can see the true pigment
of the sky, you can see the vibrant yellow

1107.79.text:
of a sunflower and the deep blue of your daughter’s
eyes.

1112.36.text:
A tender heart doesn't block out rain clouds
or tears or dying sunflowers.

1120.09.text: Allow both beauty and sadness to touch you.

1128.70.text:
Colleen, thank you so much for being here
today, it was such an honor.

1136.39.text:
For everybody watching, Yoga for Life by Colleen
Saidman Yee.

1139.64.text:
It is a fantastic, beautiful journey and I
highly recommend it.

1146.74.text:
Now Colleen and I would love to hear from
you.

1149.60.text:
If there’s one area of your life or your
body that would be well served by a little

1154.90.text:
more attention or presence or love, what would
that be?

plus some personal updates from me that I

Stay on your game and keep going for your

Thank you so much for watching and I’ll
